body: Seems to be a memory corruption. Could be some hidden BUG in the threading engine. I am not very sure. So far we haven't been able to get a quick reproducible code for the bad access bug. I will proof read the async engine code again
Yes, if it is registered as kRegisterSymbolic
a quick fix may be sleep 1s when existing to let the system have time to delete things

@mli @tqchen Although not always reproducible, it happens quite frequently in this particularly example. Also it is in the middle of training, not when the system is shutting down. Just to double check, it is OK to have multiple executors running on the same context simultaneously? (They are not sharing memory or anything, just belong to different submodules).

I think it is OK to have multiple executors to run on the same context. If this causes a problem, this should be seen as a bug. @pluskid can you make a simplified version of code that can reproduce the fault frequently?
@tqchen I am not sure if running multiple executors is the reason. But let me prepare a simple script for this.

When Upsampling can be enforced using deconv operator, why do we use a separate upsample_filt method in init_fcnxs.py for deconv parameters? https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/fcn-xs/init_fcnxs.py#L40-L42
Could you point me how this is used in ndarray operators?
@jermainewang https://github.com/tqchen/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/operator_util.cc#L270 and https://github.com/tqchen/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/operator_util.cc#L567
I think a main issue is type support. We need change a little bit of the registry to support type.

Can you help me clarify whether my understanding is right?

The whole data matrix is of size (num_of_words/batch_size, batch_size). Each column is sentence (marked with `eos` for new sentences).

In `set_rnn_inputs`, we read a row of data each time because we are doing model parallel. Because ideally, i th row of data represents the i th words of sentences. **This row of words can be fed into an unrolled lstm model**. A mini-batch is of the shape `(seq-len, batch_size)` where `seq_len` is just a proper upper bound of sentence length(a.k.a maximum unrolled lstm length). 

If my understanding is correct, I think I found a little bug here. If you look into function `replicate_data` in `model_parallel_lstm/lstm_ptb.py`,

```
   def replicate_data(x, batch_size):
        nbatch = int(x.shape[0] / batch_size)
        x_cut = x[:nbatch * batch_size]
        data = x_cut.reshape((nbatch, batch_size), order='F')
        return data
```

It does not take end of sentence into account when slicing data, so the first of each column is probably not the first of a sentence. Besides that, because we are using a mini-batch of the shape `(seq-len, batch_size)`. It is probably better to align sentences in a batch with the start of the batch instead of starting from random position within a sentence. 

I think I can fix this by adding padding and some rearrange of data into the code. It will probably reduce the training speed a little bit. But it seems a more correct way to train it.
If we can rearrange the data in an good aligning way, it will be almost the same w.r.t training speed.
use  bilinear interpolation for deconv init
After compiling, you should be able to find it under tracker folder which is a softlink to ps-lite/tracker.
It's already supported in some layers. Go check src folder.

Hi, @horserma ! 

I am doing some work(model parallelism) on the mxnet as you. I am a new mxneter, can you give me some guidance on how to “split the model by using ctx_group in bind” as you mentioned the above. 

Thank you very much.

Hi, @tuonion ,
Basically, I tried it in this way. First of all, declare the variables in different groups like:

```
with mx.AttrScope(ctx_group="dev1"):
    data = mx.symbol.Variable("data")
    conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=(7,7), workspace=workspace,
                                num_filter=64, name="conv1", pad=(3,3), stride=(2,2))

```

So data and conv1 will be assigned to "dev1". likewise, you can put something with "dev2".  Be sure that each layer is associated with a device label. Then when you bind the network, you give group2ctx a dict which could be:

```
net.bind(....,
    group2ctx={'dev1': mx.gpu(0), 'dev2': mx.gpu(1)})
```

This is what I did basically. In practice, I found it not that useful as expected because the it was not accelerated. I guess it was because the frequent communication among devices, but I am not completely sure. I hope they could provide more information or tutorial regarding this.

@tqchen Thanks a lot. It's a good idea to use different modules, just like NeuralTalk2 does.
Since fine-training CNN takes most of time of overall training, I intend to use single bucket instead of multi buckets for accelerating training. Pipeline is similar to NeuralTalk2.

@horserma , thank you for your very speedy response . Your answers  i believe will bring lots of help to me, and  I am also hope the developer can provide more information about the communication between nodes/devices. 

By the way, can you share your email-address with me? thanks very much.

I use the following code to extract images in arbitrary shapes:

``` python
import numpy as np
import mxnet as mx
import mxnet.symbol as sym
from mxnet import nd

## load symbol & params for BN-21k
input_shape = (1,3,224,224)
net_symbol = sym.load('./models/inception-21k/Inception-symbol.json')
save_dict = nd.load('./models/inception-21k/Inception-0009.params')
arg_params = {}
aux_params = {}
for k, v in save_dict.items():
    tp, name = k.split(':', 1)
    if tp == 'arg':
        arg_params[name] = v
    if tp == 'aux':
        aux_params[name] = v

## remove fc layer & set output layer
internals = net_symbol.get_internals()
net_symbol = sym.Group([internals['global_pool_output']])
# ## or, for multiple outputs:
# net_symbol = sym.Group([
#                  internals['global_pool_output'],
#                  internals['ch_concat_5b_chconcat_output'],
#                  internals['ch_concat_5a_chconcat_output'],
#                  internals['ch_concat_4e_chconcat_output'],
#                  internals['ch_concat_4d_chconcat_output'],
#                  internals['ch_concat_4c_chconcat_output'],
#              ])
arg_names = set(net_symbol.list_arguments())
arg_params = {k : v for k, v in arg_params.items() if k in arg_names}
aux_names = set(net_symbol.list_auxiliary_states())
aux_params = {k : v for k, v in aux_params.items() if k in aux_names}


## initialize executor
pred_exec = net_symbol.simple_bind(ctx=mx.gpu(), grad_req='null', data=input_shape)
pred_exec.copy_params_from(arg_params, aux_params)


## extract features
for img in img_list: # a list of images in different shapes (1,channels,height,width)
    input_shape = img.shape

    ## reshape & feed image to executor
    pred_exec = pred_exec.reshape(partial_shaping=False, allow_up_sizing=True, **{'data':input_shape})
    input_data = pred_exec.arg_dict['data']
    img_nd = mx.nd.array(img)
    img_nd.copyto(input_data)

    ## forward & get results
    pred_exec.forward(is_train=False)
    out = pred_exec.outputs
```

The key step is `reshape` the executor every time before `forward`. Is there any more efficient way to do this?

However, it might have trouble for some image shapes depending on your models. E.g., when `input_shape=(1,3,500,500)`, the above example gets the following error:

```
MXNetError: InferShape Error in ch_concat_4e_chconcat: [00:36:15] src/operator/./concat-inl.h:152: Check failed: (dshape[j]) == (tmp[j]) Incorrect shape[2]: (1,512,15,15). (first input shape: (1,960,16,16))
```

One solution is to reshape the image to a slightly different shape. E.g. `(1,3,512,512)` where `512%32 == 0`. Any better idea?
Thank you very much. I guess i got that finally.

Just did a quick scan over the codes. One question: how to do this for more complex operator like dot product? You have an SimpleUnaryOp operator class and its corrersponding wrapper for registry, which is great for ufunc operators. In my mind, I think the operator definition will be:
(1) Derive class `Operator` and `OperatorProp` to define the logic
(2) Call some provided function (or registry) to register that
(3) Done
In step (2), it will call the `OperatorProp` interface to register in both symbolic API and imperative API. Your `SimpleUnaryOp` seems to be a simplied version of (2) right?
For DotProduct, you can register it as a binary function

Currently, this registry is a specialized class for both unary and binary functions, which should be able to (hopefully)cover most use-cases, the reason why this is used is more for simplicity reason for who implements the op.
Ok. So you plan to make this a standard for new op? The old `Operator` class inheritence should not be used?

@harouwu Yes, you are absolutely right. The sentence boundary is not padded in our example of fixed-length LSTM unrolling. In the bucketing example, we use unrolling to multiple-length with padding. Here we simply treat the whole corpus as a long "sentence". As long as you forward the states properly between mini-batches, this is also a valid interpretation.

A good idea is to see if the model parallel example here could be easily incorporated with the bucketing example. My guess is that one might need to modify the executor binding code used in model.py to support the memory allocation in this situation.
The simplest trick that helps here might be to increase the batch size.

This is an enhancement to the old way, in a sense that it is simpler to do so, and works for both imperative and declarative. It is good to use it when possible.

On the other hand, the old API is still used for very complicated ops, actually this API is built on top of old API.

You can reduce it by removing the un-used ops and only link to the necessary ones. By default the amalgamation linked to a lot of things. Some function may not be needed for prediction, but nevertheless registered as ndarray function or operators

@pluskid If the C++ code will deal with `<eos>` and feed the next level of model initialized input, e.g. all zeros. It is also a valid implementation. When I was doing my research, I found similar idea called [sentence splicing](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/b8e0/008094018835255379a62df68b8ba6cc59af.pdf) they will concat short sentences to fit into a bucket with long sentences to speed up rnn training.

When you say incorporate the model_parallel one with the bucketing one, do you mean that we can design a good API for users so that they will use a flag to choose whether they want to use bucket or model parallel?
I see. I am fine with the change now.

But in my sense(I have not gone through it), the output of an unrolled level of lstm will not detect `<eos>` and give next level all zeros/ones input. I will check it myself today and update my finding.

Thanks for your help, it works!

And is there any rule that I should follow when setting minibatch size and MXNET_EXEC_INPLACE_GRAD_SUM_CAP?

In general you could ignore `MXNET_EXEC_INPLACE_GRAD_SUM_CAP` warning. Setting the mini-batch size depends on a lot of factors. Just remember that when data-parallelism is used, the mini-batch is divided into multiple devices. So a small batch-size might end up slower in this case because of communication cost.

ImageRecordIter outputs 'data' and 'softmax_label'. Your model only uses 'data' but not 'softmax_label'. You need to write a DataIter that wraps around ImageRecordIter and ignores the 'softmax_label' and only output 'data'.
You need to write your own training loop. Here is an example: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-gtc-tutorial/blob/master/tutorial.ipynb
It was added in a recent PR. See [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/setup.py#L24). Can you try with the latest code? Thanks!
@pluskid you don't need to asnumpy() to concatenate. You can allocate a new NDArray, slice along it's first dim and assign each of the outputs to a slice

cc @pluskid @javelinjs 

This PR cause a backward compatible break in symbolic API.
- Overload of scalar - symbol
  - `_DivScalar(lhs, scalar_on_left=true)` is changed to `_RDivScalar`
- Same stands for `_RPowerScalar`, `_RMinusScalar`

I have updated the python API, but maybe changes in julia and scala is needed if you overloaded the operator. Since these symbols are not frequently used, I plan to merge this in when ok

It's only about config.mk, pretty simple:

`export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++ -std=c++11 -D_FORCE_INLINES -D_MWAITXINTRIN_H_INCLUDED
export NVCC = nvcc
`

That is my solution...

Cheers

As a quick fix for the actual problem (failing with cuda OOM failure) one good fix would be to change the pooled manager to catch that error once, call ReleaseAll and make a second attempt to allocate. there is no difference between data/label in executor. The difference is in FeedForward model. If you are writing your own training loop you can use the same input as data and label
